specsnake¶

specsnake is a python package to support the handling, processing and analysis of spectrum data as they typically appear in analytical methods used in chemistry and physics.

Installation¶

specsnake can be installed directly via pip from its GitHub repository by running the following command:

pip install git+https://github.com/Darkskald/SFG.git

Basic usage¶

specsnake may be imported to be used in other python code but it also offer a command line interface for stand-alone execution which is currently under development.

base_spectrum¶

class specsnake.base_spectrum.BaseSpectrum(*args, **kwargs)¶

This class represents a basic spectrum, having an independent array of x and a dependent array of values typically representing experimental data resulting from instrumental measurements. It can be used as a generic template for many different concrete data of this structure.

get_xrange() → numpy.array¶

Returns the slice of the x values in the borders of lower to upper

get_xrange_indices(lower, upper) → Tuple[int, int]¶

Takes a high (upper) and a low (lower) target x value as argument. Returns the indices of the wavenumber array of the spectrum that are the borders of this interval.

integrate_slice(x_array: numpy.array, y_array: numpy.array) → numpy.array¶

Integrates the y_array which has a spacing given by the x_array. First it tries to apply simpson rule integration rule, but if this fails the function invokes integration via trapeziodal rule

normalize(external=None) → numpy.array¶

Normalize the spectrum’s y data either to the maximum of the y values or an external factor

yield_spectral_range() → Tuple[float, float, float]¶

returns a list containing maximum and minimum wavenumer and the number of data points

class specsnake.base_spectrum.MetaSpectrum¶

Metaclass responsible for the correct runtime behaviour of spectrum objects derived from it.

specsnake.builtin_loaders.sfg_constructor(name, data, creation_time) → specsnake.sfg_spectrum.SfgSpectrum¶

Constructor function for the actual SFG object

specsnake.builtin_loaders.sfg_extractor(file) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame¶

A function extracting the measurement data from a SFG spectral file

langmuir_isotherm¶

class specsnake.langmuir_isotherm.AverageLt(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: specsnake.langmuir_isotherm.LtIsotherm

class specsnake.langmuir_isotherm.LtIsotherm(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: specsnake.base_spectrum.BaseSpectrum

A class to represent experimental Langmuir trough isotherms, handling time, area, area per molecule and surface pressure

calculate_elasticity() → numpy.ndarray¶

Returns the surface elasticity of the isotherm

convert_to_export_dataframe()¶

This function returns a Pandas dataframe, suitable for data export to origin and similar other programs

create_pointlist(x_array)¶

Returns a list containing the index, the x_array (usually area or time) and the surface pressure. This is used for example by the GUI functions to find the closest datapoint to a mouse-defined position in the plot

derive_pressure()¶

Calculates the difference quotient of the surface pressure with respect to the area. Useful for calculation of surface elasticity

drop_ascii() → None¶

Drops an ascii file with semikolon-separated data in the form time;area;surface pressure. Intention is easy interfacing with external software like Excel or Origin

get_maximum_pressure(shrinked=None)¶

Returns the maximum measured surface pressure. Note: This property is uesd for the less-then operator implementation of this class!

get_slice(x_array, lower, upper, smooth=False)¶

Returns a slice of the x_array (usually time or area) defined by the lower and upper integer index.

plotting¶

spectrum_factory¶

class specsnake.spectrum_factory.SpectrumFactoryProvider(config)¶

A class to generate SpectrumFactories. This is the generic way to introduce new types of spectra to the logic of this package. All builtin type of spectra are available at runtime due to an instance of this class and to add new types, the underlying config dictionary may be updated.

add_new_template(name, extractor, constructor, name_transformer=None)¶

Add a new template for SpectrumFactories to the configuration. This requires the name of the template, an extractor method, a constructor method and an optional name_transformer method.

sfg_spectrum¶

class specsnake.sfg_spectrum.AverageSpectrum(*args, **kwargs)¶
class specsnake.sfg_spectrum.DummyPlotter(speclist, save=False, savedir='', savename='Default', special=None)¶

A test class to monitor the interaction of the subclasses of AbstractSpectrum with plotting routines.

class specsnake.sfg_spectrum.SfgAverager(spectra: List[specsnake.sfg_spectrum.SfgSpectrum], references=None, enforce_scale=False, name='default', debug=False, baseline=False)¶

This class takes a list of SFG spectra and generates an average spectrum of them by interpolation and averaging. It is possible to pass a dictionary of date:dppc_integral key-value-pairs in order to calculate the coverage.

average_spectra(baseline=True)¶

Function performing the averaging: it ensures that all spectra are interpolated to have the same shape, then they are averaged. A AverageSpectrum object is constructed and returned.

calc_coverage()¶

A convenience function to calculate the surface coverage

calc_reference_part()¶

Calculate the participation of each DPPC references. This is important if the spectra to average are measured on different sampling days. If, for example, 5 samples are to average and 3 of them are measured on one day, 2 on another, the final coverage is calculated by dividing the AveragedSpectrum integral by the weighted sum of the DPPC integrals of the corresponding days, in our example (2/5 * DPPC_1) + (3/5 * DPPC_2)

class specsnake.sfg_spectrum.SfgSpectrum(*args, **kwargs)¶

The SFG spectrum class is the foundation of all analysis and plotting tools. It contains a class SystematicName (or a derived class) which carries most of the metainformation. Besides holding the experimental data, it gives access to a variety of functions like normalization, peak picking etc.

calculate_ch_integral(old_baseline=False) → float¶

Calculate the integral of the spectrum in the range of 2750-3000 wavenumbers

convert_to_export_dataframe() → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame¶

This function returns a Pandas dataframe, suitable for data export to origin and similar other programs

Returns

a pandas dataframe with the spectral data

Return type

pd.DataFrame

drop_ascii() → None¶

Create an ascii file with the wavenumbers and normalized intensities

integrate_peak(x_array: numpy.ndarray, y_array: numpy.ndarray) → float¶

Numpy integration routine for numerical peak integration with the trapezoidal rule.

Parameters

  • x_array (array-like) – the x values (spacing) of the curve to integrate

  • y_array (array-like) – the y values of the curve to integrate

Returns

the area under the x/y curve

Return type

float

normalize_to_highest(intensity='default', external_norm='none') → numpy.ndarray¶

normalize an given array to its maximum, typically the normalized or raw intensity

root() → numpy.ndarray¶
Returns

the spectrum’s normalized intensity

Return type

np.ndarray

slice_by_borders(lower, upper)¶

Takes a high (upper) and a low (lower) reciprocal centimeter value as argument. Returns the indices of the wavenumber array of the spectrum that are the borders of this interval.

yield_increment()¶

Calculates stepsize and wavenumbers where the stepsize is changed

yield_maximum() → float¶
Returns

maximum intensity value of the spectrum

Return type

float

yield_spectral_range()¶

returns a list containing maximum and minimum wavenumer and the number of data points
